issues.description: Foreign language content detected without language identification
issues.elementLocation: Ce programme est également disponible en français
issues.context: This issue appears 2 times across 2 different locations in the document.
issues.remediation:
# Element Location
French text "Ce programme est également disponible en français" on page 1, plus one other instance of foreign language content in the document.

# Issue Explanation
The document contains French text that has not been properly identified with a language tag. When screen readers encounter foreign language content without proper language identification, they may pronounce the words incorrectly using the document's default language pronunciation rules.

# Step-by-Step Fix

## For the identified French text on page 1:
1. Open the PDF in Adobe Acrobat Pro
2. Open the Tags panel (View > Show/Hide > Navigation Panes > Tags)
3. Navigate to page 1 in the document
4. Locate the tag containing the French text "Ce programme est également disponible en français"
5. Right-click on this tag and select "Properties"
6. In the Object Properties dialog, go to the "Tag" tab
7. Look for the "Language" field and select "French (France)" or "French (Canada)" from the dropdown menu
8. Click "Close" to save the changes

## For the second instance of foreign language content:
1. Search for other foreign language text in the document (Edit > Find)
2. When you find the second instance, identify which tag contains this content using the Tags panel
3. Follow the same steps 5-8 above to set the appropriate language for this content

## If you need to mark just a portion of text within a larger tag:
1. You may need to split the tag to isolate the foreign language text
2. Right-click on the parent tag and select "Find Tag from Selection"
3. Use the "Reading Order" tool (Accessibility > Reading Order) to select just the foreign language text
4. Click "Create Tag" and choose an appropriate tag type (likely "Text")
5. Set the language property for this new tag as described above

# Verification
1. After making these changes, use the "Read Out Loud" feature (View > Read Out Loud) to listen to the French text
2. Verify that the screen reader attempts to pronounce the French text using French pronunciation rules
3. Check that both instances of foreign language content have been properly tagged with the appropriate language
issues.recommendation:
# Element Location
French text "Ce programme est également disponible en français" on page 1, plus one other instance of foreign language content in the document.

# Issue Explanation
The document contains French text that has not been properly identified with a language tag. When screen readers encounter foreign language content without proper language identification, they may pronounce the words incorrectly using the document's default language pronunciation rules.

# Step-by-Step Fix

## For the identified French text on page 1:
1. Open the PDF in Adobe Acrobat Pro
2. Open the Tags panel (View > Show/Hide > Navigation Panes > Tags)
3. Navigate to page 1 in the document
4. Locate the tag containing the French text "Ce programme est également disponible en français"
5. Right-click on this tag and select "Properties"
6. In the Object Properties dialog, go to the "Tag" tab
7. Look for the "Language" field and select "French (France)" or "French (Canada)" from the dropdown menu
8. Click "Close" to save the changes

## For the second instance of foreign language content:
1. Search for other foreign language text in the document (Edit > Find)
2. When you find the second instance, identify which tag contains this content using the Tags panel
3. Follow the same steps 5-8 above to set the appropriate language for this content

## If you need to mark just a portion of text within a larger tag:
1. You may need to split the tag to isolate the foreign language text
2. Right-click on the parent tag and select "Find Tag from Selection"
3. Use the "Reading Order" tool (Accessibility > Reading Order) to select just the foreign language text
4. Click "Create Tag" and choose an appropriate tag type (likely "Text")
5. Set the language property for this new tag as described above

# Verification
1. After making these changes, use the "Read Out Loud" feature (View > Read Out Loud) to listen to the French text
2. Verify that the screen reader attempts to pronounce the French text using French pronunciation rules
3. Check that both instances of foreign language content have been properly tagged with the appropriate language

issues.context: No document title found in PDF metadata
issues.remediation:
# Element Location: Document metadata (Document Properties)

## Issue Explanation
Your PDF is missing a document title in its metadata properties. The document title is essential for accessibility as it helps screen reader users identify the document and is typically the first piece of information announced when opening the PDF.

## Step-by-Step Fix

1. Open the PDF in Adobe Acrobat Pro.

2. Go to **File** > **Properties** (or press Ctrl+D / Command+D).

3. In the Document Properties dialog box, click on the **Description** tab.

4. In the **Title** field, enter a descriptive title for your document (e.g., "Course Syllabus for [Course Name]").

5. While in the Properties dialog, check the **Initial View** tab.

6. Under "Show" section, find "Show" dropdown for "Document Title" and select **Document Title** instead of "File Name" to ensure screen readers announce the title.

7. Click **OK** to save the changes.

## Verification

1. Go back to **File** > **Properties** to confirm the title appears in the Description tab.

2. Open the document and check that the title appears in the title bar of Acrobat (if you selected "Document Title" in the Initial View settings).

3. For a thorough check, use a screen reader like NVDA or JAWS to open the document and verify it announces the document title.
issues.recommendation:
# Element Location: Document metadata (Document Properties)

## Issue Explanation
Your PDF is missing a document title in its metadata properties. The document title is essential for accessibility as it helps screen reader users identify the document and is typically the first piece of information announced when opening the PDF.

## Step-by-Step Fix

1. Open the PDF in Adobe Acrobat Pro.

2. Go to **File** > **Properties** (or press Ctrl+D / Command+D).

3. In the Document Properties dialog box, click on the **Description** tab.

4. In the **Title** field, enter a descriptive title for your document (e.g., "Course Syllabus for [Course Name]").

5. While in the Properties dialog, check the **Initial View** tab.

6. Under "Show" section, find "Show" dropdown for "Document Title" and select **Document Title** instead of "File Name" to ensure screen readers announce the title.

7. Click **OK** to save the changes.

## Verification

1. Go back to **File** > **Properties** to confirm the title appears in the Description tab.

2. Open the document and check that the title appears in the title bar of Acrobat (if you selected "Document Title" in the Initial View settings).

3. For a thorough check, use a screen reader like NVDA or JAWS to open the document and verify it announces the document title.

issues.context: No H1-H6 heading tags found in PDF structure tree (document has 166 words)
issues.remediation:
# Element Location Document body (entire document lacks heading structure) # Issue Explanation Your document lacks a proper heading structure, which is essential for accessibility. Headings provide document organization and navigation for screen reader users. Without proper heading tags (H1, H2, etc.), users with disabilities cannot easily understand the document's structure or navigate between sections. # Step-by-Step Fix 1. **Open the Tags panel**: - Click on the "Tags" icon in the left sidebar, or go to View > Show/Hide > Navigation Panes > Tags 2. **Examine the current tag structure**: - Look for any existing structure. You'll likely see mostly `

` (paragraph) tags without proper heading hierarchy 3. **Identify heading content**: - Review your document to identify text that should be headings (title, section headers, subsection headers) - Plan a logical heading hierarchy (H1 for document title, H2 for main sections, H3 for subsections, etc.) 4. **Add heading tags**: - For each piece of text that should be a heading: a. Right-click on the corresponding tag in the Tags panel b. Select "Properties" c. Change the "Type" from `

` to the appropriate heading level (`

`, `

`, etc.) d. Click "Close" 5. **Alternative method using Reading Order tool**: - Click on "Accessibility" in the right panel - Select "Reading Order" tool - Draw a box around text that should be a heading - Click the appropriate heading button (Heading 1, Heading 2, etc.) in the Reading Order dialog - Repeat for all headings in the document 6. **Ensure proper nesting**: - Make sure heading levels are used in proper order (H1, then H2, then H3) - Don't skip levels (e.g., don't go from H1 directly to H3) # Verification To verify your fix worked: - Use the Tags panel to confirm heading tags (`

`, `

`, etc.) are present and in logical order - Use the Navigation panel (View > Show/Hide > Navigation Panes > Bookmarks) to see if headings appear as navigable bookmarks - Try navigating the document using heading shortcuts in a screen reader (if available) - Check that the heading structure makes logical sense for the document's content organization
issues.recommendation:

Without proper heading tags (H1, H2, etc.), users with disabilities cannot easily understand the document's structure or navigate between sections. # Step-by-Step Fix 1. **Open the Tags panel**: - Click on the "Tags" icon in the left sidebar, or go to View > Show/Hide > Navigation Panes > Tags 2. **Examine the current tag structure**: - Look for any existing structure. You'll likely see mostly `

` (paragraph) tags without proper heading hierarchy 3. **Identify heading content**: - Review your document to identify text that should be headings (title, section headers, subsection headers) - Plan a logical heading hierarchy (H1 for document title, H2 for main sections, H3 for subsections, etc.) 4. **Add heading tags**: - For each piece of text that should be a heading: a. Right-click on the corresponding tag in the Tags panel b. Select "Properties" c. Change the "Type" from `

` to the appropriate heading level (`

`, `

`, etc.) d. Click "Close" 5. **Alternative method using Reading Order tool**: - Click on "Accessibility" in the right panel - Select "Reading Order" tool - Draw a box around text that should be a heading - Click the appropriate heading button (Heading 1, Heading 2, etc.) in the Reading Order dialog - Repeat for all headings in the document 6. **Ensure proper nesting**: - Make sure heading levels are used in proper order (H1, then H2, then H3) - Don't skip levels (e.g., don't go from H1 directly to H3) # Verification To verify your fix worked: - Use the Tags panel to confirm heading tags (`

`, `

`, etc.) are present and in logical order - Use the Navigation panel (View > Show/Hide > Navigation Panes > Bookmarks) to see if headings appear as navigable bookmarks - Try navigating the document using heading shortcuts in a screen reader (if available) - Check that the heading structure makes logical sense for the document's content organization

issues.context: Image (0x0, image) on page 1 does not have alternative text
issues.remediation:
# Fix for Missing Alternative Text on Image

## Element Location
Image on page 1 of the document "syllabus_NOTaccessible (1).docx"

## Issue Explanation
The image on page 1 is missing alternative text (alt text). Alt text is essential for screen reader users to understand the content and purpose of images. Without alt text, people using assistive technology won't know what information the image conveys.

## Step-by-Step Fix

1. Open the PDF in Adobe Acrobat Pro.

2. Select the "Tools" tab in the top menu, then click on "Accessibility" to open the accessibility tools.

3. In the Accessibility panel, select "Reading Order" to open the Reading Order tool.

4. The Reading Order tool will display content regions on the page. Locate the image on page 1.

5. Right-click on the image and select "Edit Alternate Text" from the context menu.

6. In the Alternate Text dialog box that appears:
   - Enter descriptive alternative text that conveys the purpose and content of the image
   - If the image is decorative only, check the "Decorative figure" checkbox
   - Click "OK" to save the alt text

7. Alternatively, if you can't find the image using the Reading Order tool:
   - Open the Tags panel (View > Show/Hide > Navigation Panes > Tags)
   - Navigate through the tag structure to find the image tag (usually labeled as "Figure")
   - Right-click on the Figure tag and select "Properties"
   - In the Object Properties dialog, go to the "Tag" tab and enter appropriate alt text in the "Alternate Text" field
   - Click "Close" to save

## Verification
To verify the fix worked:
1. Right-click on the image and select "Edit Alternate Text" to confirm your alt text is saved
2. Run the Accessibility Full Check again on just this specific rule to confirm the issue is resolved
3. Use the Read Out Loud feature (View > Read Out Loud) to hear how a screen reader would present the image with its new alt text

Remember: Good alt text should be concise but descriptive, conveying the purpose and content of the image without being overly lengthy.
issues.recommendation:
# Fix for Missing Alternative Text on Image

## Element Location
Image on page 1 of the document "syllabus_NOTaccessible (1).docx"

## Issue Explanation
The image on page 1 is missing alternative text (alt text). Alt text is essential for screen reader users to understand the content and purpose of images. Without alt text, people using assistive technology won't know what information the image conveys.

## Step-by-Step Fix

1. Open the PDF in Adobe Acrobat Pro.

2. Select the "Tools" tab in the top menu, then click on "Accessibility" to open the accessibility tools.

3. In the Accessibility panel, select "Reading Order" to open the Reading Order tool.

4. The Reading Order tool will display content regions on the page. Locate the image on page 1.

5. Right-click on the image and select "Edit Alternate Text" from the context menu.

6. In the Alternate Text dialog box that appears:
   - Enter descriptive alternative text that conveys the purpose and content of the image
   - If the image is decorative only, check the "Decorative figure" checkbox
   - Click "OK" to save the alt text

7. Alternatively, if you can't find the image using the Reading Order tool:
   - Open the Tags panel (View > Show/Hide > Navigation Panes > Tags)
   - Navigate through the tag structure to find the image tag (usually labeled as "Figure")
   - Right-click on the Figure tag and select "Properties"
   - In the Object Properties dialog, go to the "Tag" tab and enter appropriate alt text in the "Alternate Text" field
   - Click "Close" to save

## Verification
To verify the fix worked:
1. Right-click on the image and select "Edit Alternate Text" to confirm your alt text is saved
2. Run the Accessibility Full Check again on just this specific rule to confirm the issue is resolved
3. Use the Read Out Loud feature (View > Read Out Loud) to hear how a screen reader would present the image with its new alt text

Remember: Good alt text should be concise but descriptive, conveying the purpose and content of the image without being overly lengthy.

issues.elementLocation: Ce programme est également disponible en français
issues.context: This issue appears 2 times across 2 different locations in the document.
issues.remediation: Select the foreign language text in Acrobat and set its language property: Right-click > Properties > Tag > Language. This fix should be applied to all 2 instances.

issues.context: No document title found in PDF metadata
issues.remediation: Add a descriptive and unique document title in the document properties (File > Properties > Title).

issues.context: No H1-H6 heading tags found in PDF structure tree (document has 166 words)
issues.remediation: Use built-in heading styles (Heading 1, Heading 2, etc.) in a logical, hierarchical order to organize content. In Acrobat: Use the Tags panel to tag headings as H1, H2, H3, etc.

issues.context: Image (0x0, image) on page 1 does not have alternative text
issues.remediation: Add descriptive alternative text to the image on page 1. In Adobe Acrobat: Right-click the image > Edit Image > Add Alternative Text.
